data.text: @MTaylornz @heathcliff_mr @nzherald What part of unrelated don't you understand?

@JustineMercer3 @nzherald Unfortunately they word it like this to cause fear on purpose, fear = more compliance for new laws and more money for news stations. Win win for the government and media. They word it like this in America too, it’s not a accident.

@ghostyy76 @nzherald That’s how they worded in UK , and finally admitted most were in for something else and caught whilst in hospital , just went on these number charts as COVID hospital , like they were all rushed in because . A little clarity would be nice

@whodacky @heathcliff_mr @nzherald Are you a coroner? The reason for death will be determined by the doctors and coroner and recorded accordingly.

Yet you sit here throwing reckons about how you think it should go despite, likely having no idea what you’re talking about.
@MTaylornz @heathcliff_mr @nzherald No, all I’m saying is that a positive case who dies from an unrelated condition shouldn’t be labeled a Covid death. Nice bow you were drawing though

@whodacky @heathcliff_mr @nzherald The implication of your first statement and follow up responses. You’re making the case that if someone goes to hospital without covid, gets it and dies means it’s nothing to do with covid and somehow a hoax.

You’re not a medical expert yet make claims like you are…
@heathcliff_mr @whodacky @nzherald Yes. It literally is a coincidence. Half the the “Covid deaths” this week have been in hospital receiving PALLIATIVE care!
@heathcliff_mr @OG_dissident_ @whodacky @nzherald Yea apparently the covid virus kills you by gun shot. Crazy virus.
@heathcliff_mr @SeahawkSilver @whodacky @nzherald LOL. Do you know how delusional you sound?

@OG_dissident_ @SeahawkSilver @whodacky @nzherald The point is that you can say correlation does not equal causation for nearly all medical events occurring after vaccination because it's been proven that vaccination doesn't cause them. On the other hand, the Covid virus is known to cause medical problems.
